Members of the Board NAEB
February 9, 1954
I mentioned this side to Mitch. He intends to check
the problem. Perhaps his discussion with Columbia will
break through the argument. It seems to me that the
master should be corrected before any order goes in for
a new pressing of albums.
In general comment, the reputation of EBF and of its field
personnel in my region is excellent. I assume that all directors
are able to judge the organization in their individual regions, aid
that the reputation of EBF is of high order. In my opinion EBF
will sell the albums in quantity if this can be done. If there
isn9t a market, we have little to lose anyway.
A prompt answer is needed by EBF since a catalogue is in
preparation. Prominent space xvould be given WAEB in the publica¬
tion but printing cannot be delayed much longer since the catalogue
is to be used in selling this spring.
The alternative to EBF is to have the bookstore at the University
of Illinois distribute the albums. They would accept orders, bill,
mail, store. NAEB would still have to maintain the supply but would
have no paper work. Under this arrangement WAEB would receive $20
from a list price of $25. This would leave a net per album of
approximately $13 instead of $1Q~$12 under the EBF arrangement. Of
course, NAEB would not have increased it's price but neither would it
have a conntry-wide promotion nor a staff of 40 experienced salesmen
to increase the sales.
Will you please write to Harry Skornia to indicate whether
you favor distribution via EBF or the U. of I. Bookstore. I know
that my presentation is colored by my own judgment of the course
for us to choose. As I see it, the odds favor the gamble to see
whether real sales effort will bring a significant return.
Sincerely,
Allen Miller
